text: In which land did Job live?
verseText: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job, and that man was blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil.

text: How is Job described in the first verse of the book?
verseText: There was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job, and that man was blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil.

text: Who came before God among the 'sons of God' and accused Job?
verseText: Now there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the LORD, and Satan also came among them.

text: What was Satan's primary accusation against Job?
options: Job only feared God because he was blessed
verseText: Then Satan answered the LORD and said, “Does Job fear God for no reason? Have you not put a hedge around him and his house and all that he has, on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land. But stretch out your hand and touch all that he has, and he will curse you to your face.”

text: What was the first catastrophe that befell Job?
options: His livestock were stolen and servants killed
verseText: and there came a messenger to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them, and the Sabeans fell upon them and took them and struck down the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”

text: How did Job react immediately after losing his possessions and children?
options: He tore his robe, shaved his head, and worshiped
verseText: Then Job arose and tore his robe and shaved his head and fell on the ground and worshiped. And he said, “Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.”

text: What did God permit Satan to do to Job the second time, with a limitation?
options: Afflict his body, but spare his life
verseText: And the LORD said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your hand; only spare his life.”

text: What affliction did Satan strike Job with?
options: Painful sores from head to toe
verseText: So Satan went out from the presence of the LORD and struck Job with loathsome sores from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.

text: What did Job's wife advise him to do in his suffering?
verseText: Then his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast your integrity? Curse God and die.”

text: Who were the three friends who came to comfort Job?
verseText: Now when Job's three friends heard of all this evil that had come upon him, they came each from his own place, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They made an appointment together to come to show him sympathy and comfort him.

text: How many sons and daughters did Job have initially?
verseText: There were born to him seven sons and three daughters.

text: What did Job regularly do on behalf of his children in case they had sinned?
verseText: And when the days of the feast had run their course, Job would send and consecrate them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my children have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did continually.

text: Besides livestock and servants, what other major loss did Job suffer in the first wave of catastrophes?
verseText: While he was yet speaking, there came another and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother's house, and behold, a great wind came across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young people, and they are dead, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”

text: What phrase did Job utter, expressing submission after his initial losses?
options: The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.
Satan has done this to me.
verseText: And he said, “Naked I came from my mother's womb, and naked shall I return. The LORD gave, and the LORD has taken away; blessed be the name of the LORD.”

text: In the second heavenly council, what did Satan claim Job would do if his own body were afflicted?
verseText: But stretch out your hand and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse you to your face.

text: What did Job use to scrape his sores?
verseText: And he took a piece of broken pottery with which to scrape himself while he sat in the ashes.

text: How did Job respond to his wife's suggestion to curse God?
options: He rebuked her for speaking foolishly
He asked her to pray for him
verseText: But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women would speak. Shall we receive good from God, and shall we not receive evil?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.

text: How long did Job's three friends sit with him in silence before speaking?
verseText: And they sat with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his suffering was very great.

text: What did Job curse in his first speech after the silence?
verseText: After this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.

text: Who was the first friend to speak in response to Job's lament?
verseText: Then Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:

text: What was the main point of Eliphaz's first speech?
options: Job must have sinned to deserve such suffering.
Satan is the cause of Job's problems.
verseText: (Summary) Eliphaz suggests that the innocent do not perish and suffering comes from wrongdoing, recounting a vision emphasizing human impurity before God and advising Job to seek God.

text: Eliphaz recounted a vision. What was the central message of the spirit in his vision?
options: Can a mortal be pure before God?
verseText: ‘Can mortal man be in the right before God? Can a man be pure before his Maker?’

text: In his reply to Eliphaz, what did Job wish God would do?
options: Crush him and end his life
Explain the reason for his suffering
verseText: “Oh that I might have my request, and that God would grant my desire, that it would please God to crush me, that he would let loose his hand and cut me off!

text: How did Job describe his friends' comfort in his first reply?
options: Like deceitful brooks that dry up
verseText: My brothers are treacherous as a torrent-bed, as torrential streams that pass away,

text: Who was the second friend to speak to Job?
verseText: Then Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:

text: What analogy did Bildad use to illustrate the fate of those who forget God?
verseText: “Can papyrus grow where there is no marsh? Can reeds flourish where there is no water? While yet in flower and not cut down, they wither before any other plant. Such are the paths of all who forget God; the hope of the godless shall perish.”

text: What was Bildad's main advice to Job?
options: Seek God earnestly and plead for mercy
verseText: If you will seek God and plead with the Almighty for mercy, if you are pure and upright, surely then he will rouse himself for you and restore your rightful habitation.

text: In his reply to Bildad, Job questioned how a man could be what before God?
verseText: “Truly I know that it is so: But how can a man be in the right before God?”

text: Job expressed a desire for what kind of intermediary between himself and God?
verseText: There is no arbiter between us, who might lay his hand on us both.

text: Who was the third friend to speak to Job?
verseText: Then Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:

text: What did Zophar accuse Job of hiding?
verseText: But oh, that God would speak and open his lips to you, and that he would tell you the secrets of wisdom! For he is manifold in understanding. Know then that God exacts of you less than your guilt deserves.

text: Zophar suggested that if Job repented, his life would be what?
verseText: And your life will be brighter than the noonday; its darkness will be like the morning.

text: In response to Zophar, Job sarcastically claimed that what would die with his friends?
verseText: “No doubt you are the people, and wisdom will die with you.”

text: Job asserted his desire to argue his case directly with whom?
verseText: But I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to argue my case with God.

text: How did Job describe his friends' attempts at comfort in chapter 13?
verseText: As for you, you whitewash with lies; worthless physicians are you all.

text: Job compared human life to what transient things in chapter 14?
options: A fleeting shadow and a flower
A flowing river and a cloud
verseText: “Man who is born of a woman is few of days and full of trouble. He comes out like a flower and withers; he flees like a shadow and continues not.”

text: What question did Job ponder regarding death in chapter 14?
options: If a man dies, shall he live again?
Do the dead remember the living?
verseText: If a man dies, shall he live again? All the days of my service I would wait, till my renewal should come.

text: In the second cycle of speeches, what did Eliphaz accuse Job's words of being?
verseText: “Should a wise man answer with windy knowledge, and fill his belly with the east wind? Should he argue in unprofitable talk, or with words with which he can do no good?”

text: Eliphaz argued that the wicked live in constant fear of what?
verseText: The sound of terrors is in his ears; in prosperity the destroyer will come upon him. He does not believe that he will return out of darkness, and he is marked for the sword.

text: How did Job describe his friends in his reply during the second cycle?
verseText: “I have heard many such things; miserable comforters are you all.”

text: Job claimed that God had become like what to him?
verseText: I was at ease, and he broke me apart; he seized me by the neck and dashed me to pieces; he set me up as his target; his archers surround me.

text: Despite his suffering, Job expressed confidence in having what in heaven?
verseText: Even now, behold, my witness is in heaven, and he who testifies for me is on high.

text: In Bildad's second speech, he described the fate of the wicked using what imagery?
verseText: “Indeed, the light of the wicked is put out, and the flame of his fire does not shine. The light is dark in his tent, and his lamp above him is put out.”

text: Bildad implied Job's suffering was due to him being caught in what?
options: A net of his own making (sin)
verseText: For he is cast into a net by his own feet, and he walks on its mesh.

text: In his famous response in chapter 19, Job expressed a profound hope, stating 'I know that my ______ lives'.
verseText: For I know that my Redeemer lives, and at the last he will stand upon the earth.

text: What did Job believe he would see, even after his skin was destroyed?
verseText: And after my skin has been thus destroyed, yet in my flesh I shall see God,

text: How did Job describe the reaction of his relatives and acquaintances to his suffering?
options: They were estranged and alienated from him
verseText: “He has put my brothers far from me, and those who knew me are wholly estranged from me. My relatives have failed me, my close friends have forgotten me.”

text: In Zophar's second speech, what did he claim about the prosperity of the wicked?
options: It is a sign of God's favor
verseText: that the exulting of the wicked is short, and the joy of the godless but for a moment?

text: Zophar compared the wicked person's ill-gotten gains to what?
verseText: “Though evil is sweet in his mouth, though he hides it under his tongue, though he is loath to let it go and holds it in his mouth, yet his food is turned in his stomach; it is the venom of cobras within him.”

text: In his reply to Zophar (chapter 21), what observation did Job make that contradicted his friends' arguments?
options: The wicked often live long, prosperous lives
verseText: Why do the wicked live, reach old age, and grow mighty in power?

text: Job questioned why the punishment for the wicked doesn't always fall on them but sometimes on whom?
verseText: You say, ‘God stores up their iniquity for their children.’ Let him pay it out to them themselves, that they may know it.

text: In the third cycle, what specific sins did Eliphaz accuse Job of committing?
options: Exploiting the poor, withholding water, mistreating widows/orphans
verseText: For you have exacted pledges of your brothers for nothing and stripped the naked of their clothing. You have given no water to the weary to drink, and you have withheld bread from the hungry... You have sent widows away empty-handed, and the arms of the fatherless were crushed.

text: What did Eliphaz advise Job to do to find peace and restoration?
options: Agree with God and be at peace
verseText: “Agree with God, and be at peace; thereby good will come to you.”

text: In his response (chapter 23), what was Job's primary lament regarding God?
options: He could not find God to plead his case
verseText: Oh, that I knew where I might find him, that I might come even to his seat!

text: Despite his inability to find God, Job expressed confidence that God knew what?
options: The location of his lost wealth
The way that he took (his path/integrity)
The date his suffering would end
verseText: But he knows the way that I take; when he has tried me, I shall come out as gold.

text: In chapter 24, Job lamented the fact that God does not seem to set specific times for what?
verseText: “Why are not times of judgment kept by the Almighty, and why do those who know him never see his days?”

text: Bildad's third speech (chapter 25) is notably short. What is its main theme?
options: Man's insignificance and impurity compared to God's majesty
verseText: How then can man be in the right before God? How can he who is born of woman be pure? Behold, even the moon is not bright, and the stars are not pure in his eyes; how much less man, who is a maggot, and the son of man, who is a worm!”

text: In Job's response starting in chapter 26, he sarcastically questions how much his friends have helped whom?
options: The powerless and the arm that has no strength
verseText: “How you have helped him who has no power! How you have saved the arm that has no strength!”

text: Job described God's power over creation, including stretching out the north over what?
verseText: He stretches out the north over the void and hangs the earth on nothing.

text: In chapter 27, Job took an oath, vowing that his lips would not speak what?
verseText: my lips will not speak falsehood, and my tongue will not utter deceit.

text: Chapter 28 is a hymn about wisdom. Where does it say wisdom cannot be found?
options: In the land of the living or the deep sea
verseText: “But where shall wisdom be found? And where is the place of understanding? Man does not know its worth, and it is not found in the land of the living. The deep says, ‘It is not in me,’ and the sea says, ‘It is not with me.’”

text: According to chapter 28, what is the beginning (or essence) of wisdom?
verseText: And he said to man, ‘Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is wisdom, and to turn away from evil is understanding.’”

text: In chapter 29, what time period did Job long for?
options: The months of old when God watched over him
The time before his children were born
verseText: “Oh, that I were as in the months of old, as in the days when God watched over me,”

text: How did Job describe his former status and actions in the community (chapter 29)?
options: He was respected, helped the poor, and upheld justice
He was feared for his harshness
verseText: (Summary) Job recounts how he was respected by young and old, sat as chief, delivered the poor and fatherless, was eyes to the blind and feet to the lame.

text: In contrast to his former respect, how did Job say he was treated now (chapter 30)?
options: Mocked and scorned, even by younger men
verseText: “But now they laugh at me, men who are younger than I, whose fathers I would have disdained to set with the dogs of my flock.”

text: Job described his physical suffering in chapter 30, saying his skin turned what color?
verseText: My skin turns black and falls from me, and my bones burn with heat.

text: Chapter 31 contains Job's final oath of innocence. What is one type of sin he swore he had not committed?
verseText: “I have made a covenant with my eyes; how then could I gaze at a virgin?”

text: In his oath, Job declared he had not rejoiced at the ruin of whom?
verseText: “If I have rejoiced at the ruin of him who hated me, or exulted when evil overtook him”

text: Job swore he had not put his trust in what, instead of God?
verseText: “If I have made gold my trust or called fine gold my confidence, if I have rejoiced because my wealth was abundant or because my hand had found much...”

text: Job concluded his oath by wishing what?
verseText: Oh, that I had one to hear me! (Here is my signature! Let the Almighty answer me!) Oh, that I had the indictment written by my adversary!

text: After Job's final speech, why did his three friends stop answering him?
options: They were convinced by his arguments
Because he was righteous in his own eyes
God told them to be silent
verseText: So these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.

text: Who began to speak after Job and his three friends fell silent?
options: Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite
verseText: Then Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, burned with anger. He burned with anger at Job because he justified himself rather than God.

text: Why was Elihu initially hesitant to speak?
options: He was younger than the other men
He didn't know what to say
verseText: And Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said: “I am young in years, and you are aged; therefore I was timid and afraid to declare my opinion to you. I said, ‘Let days speak, and many years teach wisdom.’”

text: What did Elihu claim gives understanding, rather than just age?
options: The spirit in man, the breath of the Almighty
verseText: But it is the spirit in man, the breath of the Almighty, that makes him understand.

text: Elihu was angry with Job primarily for justifying whom?
verseText: He burned with anger at Job because he justified himself rather than God.

text: Elihu was angry with the three friends for what reason?
options: They had found no answer to Job, yet condemned him
verseText: He burned with anger also at Job's three friends because they had found no answer, although they had declared Job to be in the wrong.

text: In chapter 33, Elihu suggested God speaks to people in what ways, besides direct speech?
verseText: For God speaks in one way, and in two, though man does not perceive it. In a dream, in a vision of the night... or he is disciplined with pain on his bed...

text: According to Elihu, what is one purpose of suffering?
options: To keep man from pride and redeem his soul
verseText: that he may turn man aside from his deed and conceal pride from a man... Behold, God does all these things, twice, three times, with a man, to bring back his soul from the pit, that he may be lighted with the light of life.

text: In chapter 34, Elihu strongly defended which attribute of God against Job's complaints?
verseText: “Therefore, hear me, you men of understanding: far be it from God that he should do wickedness, and from the Almighty that he should do wrong... Of a truth, God will not do wickedly, and the Almighty will not pervert justice.”

text: Elihu argued that God is not indifferent because He is the one who gave humans what?
verseText: If he should set his heart to it and gather to himself his spirit and his breath, all flesh would perish together, and man would return to dust.

text: In chapter 35, Elihu addressed Job's claim that there is no advantage to being what?
verseText: “Do you think this to be just? Do you say, ‘It is my right before God,’ that you ask, ‘What advantage have I? How am I better off than if I had sinned?’”

text: Elihu argued that human sin or righteousness does not affect whom directly?
verseText: If you have sinned, what do you accomplish against him? ... If you are righteous, what do you give to him?... Your wickedness concerns a man like yourself, and your righteousness a son of man.

text: Elihu criticized Job for crying out under oppression but not asking what?
verseText: “Because of the multitude of oppressions people cry out; they call for help because of the arm of the mighty. But none says, ‘Where is God my Maker, who gives songs in the night...'

text: In chapter 36, Elihu began to extol which aspect of God?
verseText: “Behold, God is exalted in his power; who is a teacher like him?... Behold, God is great, and we know him not; the number of his years is unsearchable.”

text: Elihu used natural phenomena like rain, clouds, and lightning to illustrate what?
verseText: (Summary) Elihu describes how God draws up water, distills rain, spreads clouds, and directs lightning, showing His control over nature for sustenance and judgment.

text: Elihu continued his description of God's majesty in nature in chapter 37, mentioning snow, rain, and what else?
verseText: For to the snow he says, ‘Fall on the earth,’ likewise to the downpour, his mighty downpour... From its chamber comes the whirlwind, and cold from the scattering winds. By the breath of God ice is given, and the broad waters are frozen fast.

text: What question did Elihu pose to Job regarding the balancing of the clouds?
options: Do you know how the clouds are balanced?
verseText: Do you know the balancings of the clouds, the wondrous works of him who is perfect in knowledge,

text: Elihu concluded his speeches by stating that the Almighty is beyond human finding, excelling in what?
verseText: The Almighty—we cannot find him; he is great in power; justice and abundant righteousness he will not violate.

text: From where did the LORD answer Job after Elihu finished speaking?
verseText: Then the LORD answered Job out of the whirlwind and said:

text: What was God's first challenge to Job?
options: 'Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?'
'Where were your friends when you suffered?'
verseText: “Who is this that darkens counsel by words without knowledge?”

text: God commanded Job to prepare himself like a man for what purpose?
verseText: Dress for action like a man; I will question you, and you make it known to me.

text: God's questions to Job primarily concerned what?
options: The creation and workings of the natural world
verseText: (Summary) God questions Job about the foundations of the earth, the sea, dawn, death, light, darkness, snow, hail, stars, clouds, rain, and various animals.

text: God asked Job where he was when God laid what?
verseText: “Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth? Tell me, if you have understanding.”

text: God questioned Job about his knowledge of the storehouses of what?
verseText: “Have you entered the storehouses of the snow, or have you seen the storehouses of the hail,”

text: God highlighted His care for animals by asking Job if he provides food for which creature and its young?
verseText: “Can you hunt the prey for the lion, or satisfy the appetite of the young lions, when they crouch in their dens or lie in wait in their thicket?”

text: Which bird did God describe as treating its young harshly, yet possessing great speed?
verseText: (Summary) God describes the ostrich leaving her eggs on the ground, lacking wisdom, but scorning the horse and rider when she runs.

text: God questioned Job about his ability to give strength and its majestic mane to which animal?
verseText: “Do you give the horse his might? Do you clothe his neck with a mane?”

text: After God's first speech, how did Job initially respond?
options: He said he was small and would lay his hand on his mouth
verseText: Then Job answered the LORD and said: “Behold, I am of small account; what shall I answer you? I lay my hand on my mouth. I have spoken once, and I will not answer; twice, but I will proceed no further.”

text: In God's second speech, He challenged Job, asking if Job could annul God's what?
verseText: Will you even put me in the wrong? Will you condemn me that you may be in the right?

text: God described a powerful land creature called Behemoth. What did it eat?
verseText: “Behold, Behemoth, which I made as I made you; he eats grass like an ox.”

text: Where did God say Behemoth rests?
options: Under the lotus plants, in the marshes
verseText: Under the lotus plants he lies, in the shelter of the reeds and in the marsh. For his shade the lotus trees cover him; the willows of the brook surround him.

text: God then described a fearsome sea creature. What is it called?
verseText: “Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook or press down his tongue with a cord?”

text: How did God describe Leviathan's scales?
options: Like rows of shields, tightly sealed
verseText: His back is made of rows of shields, shut up closely as with a seal.

text: What did God say comes out of Leviathan's mouth?
verseText: Out of his mouth go flaming torches; sparks of fire leap forth. Out of his nostrils comes forth smoke... His breath kindles coals, and a flame comes forth from his mouth.

text: God stated that Leviathan regards iron as what?
verseText: He counts iron as straw, and bronze as rotten wood.

text: How did God summarize Leviathan's nature?
options: King over all the sons of pride
verseText: He sees everything that is high; he is king over all the sons of pride.”

text: After God's second speech, what did Job acknowledge about God's power and purpose?
options: God can do all things, and no purpose of His can be thwarted
God's power is less than Satan's
verseText: “I know that you can do all things, and that no purpose of yours can be thwarted.”

text: What did Job admit about his own words spoken during his suffering?
options: He uttered what he did not understand
His friends forced him to say them
verseText: ‘Who is this that hides counsel without knowledge?’ Therefore I have uttered what I did not understand, things too wonderful for me, which I did not know.

text: Job stated he had previously heard of God by the hearing of the ear, but now what?
verseText: I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye sees you;

text: What was Job's final response to God?
options: He despised himself and repented in dust and ashes
verseText: therefore I despise myself, and repent in dust and ashes.”

text: After Job's repentance, who did God express anger towards?
verseText: After the LORD had spoken these words to Job, the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite: “My anger burns against you and your two friends, for you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has.”

text: Why was God angry with Job's three friends?
options: They had not spoken rightly about God, as Job had
verseText: ...for you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has.”

text: What did God command Eliphaz and his friends to do?
options: Offer a large burnt offering and have Job pray for them
verseText: Now therefore take seven bulls and seven rams and go to my servant Job and offer up for yourselves a burnt offering. And my servant Job shall pray for you, for I will accept his prayer not to deal with you according to your folly.

text: Whose prayer did God say He would accept on behalf of the friends?
verseText: And my servant Job shall pray for you, for I will accept his prayer...

text: When did the LORD restore Job's fortunes?
options: When Job prayed for his friends
verseText: And the LORD restored the fortunes of Job, when he had prayed for his friends. And the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before.

text: How much did God restore to Job compared to what he had before?
verseText: And the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before.

text: Who came to Job after his restoration to comfort and console him?
options: All his brothers, sisters, and former acquaintances
verseText: Then came to him all his brothers and sisters and all who had known him before, and ate bread with him in his house. And they showed him sympathy and comforted him for all the evil that the LORD had brought upon him.

text: What did each person give Job during this visit?
options: A piece of money and a gold ring
verseText: And each of them gave him a piece of money and a ring of gold.

text: How many sheep, camels, yoke of oxen, and female donkeys did Job have after his restoration?
options: 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, 500 female donkeys
10,000 sheep, 5,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, 1,000 female donkeys
14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, 1,000 female donkeys
20,000 sheep, 10,000 camels, 2,000 yoke of oxen, 2,000 female donkeys
verseText: And the LORD blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning. And he had 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.

text: How many sons and daughters did Job have after his restoration?
verseText: He had also seven sons and three daughters.

text: What were the names of Job's three daughters born after his suffering?
verseText: And he called the name of the first daughter Jemimah, and the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-happuch.

text: What was said about the beauty of Job's daughters?
options: No women were found so beautiful in all the land
verseText: And in all the land there were no women so beautiful as Job's daughters.

text: What unusual thing did Job give his daughters along with his sons?
verseText: And their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.

text: How long did Job live after his suffering?
verseText: And after this Job lived 140 years,

text: How many generations of his descendants did Job see?
verseText: ...and saw his sons, and his sons' sons, four generations.

text: How is the end of Job's life described?
options: He died old and full of days
verseText: And Job died, an old man, and full of days.

text: What fundamental question does the book of Job primarily explore?
options: The problem of suffering, especially undeserved suffering
verseText: The book explores theodicy - the vindication of divine goodness and providence in view of the existence of evil and suffering.

text: The dialogues between Job and his friends represent different perspectives on what?
options: The best way to get rich
The cause of suffering and God's justice
verseText: The friends generally represent the traditional view that suffering is always a direct result of sin, while Job challenges this view based on his experience.

text: What does God's response from the whirlwind emphasize?
options: The specific reasons for Job's suffering
God's infinite wisdom and power compared to human limitations
verseText: God's speeches highlight His sovereignty over creation and the limits of human understanding, rather than directly answering Job's 'why'.

text: What is a key takeaway from Job's final repentance?
options: He finally admitted his secret sins
He acknowledged God's sovereignty and his own limited perspective
He realized his friends were right
He gave up on understanding God
verseText: Job's repentance stems from a profound encounter with God's majesty, leading him to trust God despite unanswered questions.

text: The restoration of Job's fortunes serves to demonstrate what?
options: God's ultimate faithfulness and blessing for those who endure
verseText: The restoration shows God's approval of Job's faithfulness through trial and His ability to restore beyond measure.

text: What literary form constitutes the main body of the Book of Job (chapters 3-42:6)?
verseText: The prologue and epilogue are narrative prose, but the extensive dialogues and speeches are in Hebrew poetry.

text: Elihu's speeches serve as a bridge between which parts of the book?
options: Dialogues with friends and God's speeches
verseText: Elihu speaks after the three friends fall silent and before God answers Job from the whirlwind, offering a different perspective.

text: The concept of a 'Redeemer' (Go'el) mentioned by Job in chapter 19 traditionally referred to what?
options: A kinsman who avenges, defends, or buys back family/property
verseText: The Go'el was a crucial figure in Israelite society responsible for upholding family rights and honor, which Job applies hopefully to God or a divine intermediary.

text: Does the Book of Job provide a simple, direct answer to why good people suffer?
options: Yes, it's always due to sin.
Yes, it's always a test from God.
No, it explores the complexity and mystery surrounding suffering and divine justice.
verseText: The book resists easy answers, ultimately pointing to trust in God's wisdom even when His ways are incomprehensible.
